awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Non-Equilibrium Plasma Coupled Rapid Compression Machine
awd_abstract_narration:
Development of next generation high-efficiency, low-emission engines require extending the pressure and temperature operation ranges beyond current limits. A novel approach known as the plasma-assisted combustion (PAC) has recently demonstrated considerable promise, which can play an important role in enhancing the basic combustion process. However, the details of exact chemical enhancement mechanisms remain largely unknown. The main goal of this project is to design, fabricate and assemble a unique plasma coupled experimental apparatus that will enable the scientific investigation of PAC at engine relevant conditions. Additionally, additive manufacturing techniques will be leveraged to fabricate customized metallic components of complex geometries not possible with traditional subtractive methods. This project will also include educational and workforce development activities to train a new generation of engineers and scientists with the interdisciplinary technical skills. These efforts will ultimately reduce fuel consumption, ensure energy security, mitigate the environmental impact of next generation engines, and position the US as a leader in the development of innovative technologies for transportation/energy applications.

This MRI program will allow a multi-disciplinary group of researchers to develop a unique plasma coupled rapid compression (PRCM), that is capable of compressing a gaseous fuel and oxidizer mixture to instigate combustion while under the effects of a non-equilibrium plasma. Taking advantage of additive manufacturing, the modularity of this device will allow a variety of different diagnostic measurements to be performed in order to accurately observe plasma formation, and ultimately interpret auto-ignition chemistry and physical-chemical interactions with and without the influence of a plasma. The device also provides well-defined boundary conditions to compliment experimental studies with numerical modelling approaches. Based on this instrument, the project aims to elucidate the following scientific investigations: a) understand the kinetic oxidation scheme of low-temperature combustion (cool flame chemistry) of hydrocarbon fuels, practical fuels, and surrogate fuels; b) understand the combustion characteristics of new generation biofuels derived from algae and non-food source terrestrial biomass; c) understand the role of plasma chemical effects on the kinetic oxidation scheme of cool flame chemistry of fuels; and d) demonstrate PAC as a means to enable advanced compression ignition strategies. Experimental data derived from this device will be used to develop and validate accurate plasma-specific and low-temperature chemical kinetic models for use in predictive simulations tools, thus enabling the design of future engines and improved combustion systems.

This project is jointly funded by CBET-MRI Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Current efforts to accelerate the development of high-efficiency, low-emission vehicles is restricted by our lack of fundamental understanding of how fuels burn at engine-like conditions, but more importantly, it requires the development of new methods to enhance and control combustion processes beyond the limits of normal flammability, often at higher pressures, lower temperatures and leaner conditions. The efficacy of plasma-assisted combustion (PAC) to enhance the basic combustion phenomena has been demonstrated in the past, but an understanding of the chemical mechanisms that lead to such enhancements and its demonstration towards practical engines remains limited. This MRI project contributed and complemented these ongoing efforts by developing a unique plasma coupled rapid compression machine (PRCM). This device has the capability of performing a wide range of diagnostic techniques (both in-situ and ex-situ) to achieve accurate observation, and ultimately interpretation of auto-ignition chemistry and physical-chemical interactions with and without the influence a low-temperature plasma (LTP).

 

Intellectual Merit: The developed PRCM device is a single-piston experimental device capable of compressing (P < 80 bar, T < 1000 K) a gaseous fuel and oxidizer mixture to induce constant volume combustion, with the added capability of perturbing the process mixture by nanosecond duration high-voltage pulses (<40 kV), at high pulse repetition rates (~10kHz), to induce a low-temperature plasma. This device is ideally suited to study combustion kinetics as it provides well defined boundary conditions to enable numerical modeling initiatives, but also provides practical relevance by obtaining experimental conditions indicative of modern engines. The modularity of this device allows for a variety of diagnostics to be performed, including (i) a time-resolved high-pressure transducer to measure ignition delay, and resultant heat-release rate, (ii) optical access to perform real-time in-cylinder imaging to observe flame development and plasma formation, as well as optical diagnostic techniques to measure radical species. With these enabled capabilities, the use of this instrument aims to elucidate the following scientific investigations: a) understand the kinetic oxidation scheme of low-temperature combustion (cool flame chemistry) of hydrocarbon fuels, practical fuels, and surrogate fuels; b) understand the combustion characteristics of new generation biofuels; c) understand the role of plasma chemical effects on the kinetic oxidation scheme of cool flame chemistry of fuels; and d) demonstrate PAC as a means to enhance the combustion process to improve the performance characteristics of advanced compression ignition engines. Experimental data derived from this device will also be used to numerically construct, validate and analyze accurate plasma-specific and low-temperature combustion reactions mechanisms that are significantly lacking in the literature.

 

Broader Impacts: The development of this instrument will contribute to advancing LTP technologies as a viable method to improve the operability of combustion systems for vehicular, aerospace, and energy-generation applications. The device design and the obtained experimental kinetic data will be openly shared with the combustion research community to facilitate combustion kinetic mechanism development efforts. The availability of this device as a multi-user research and learning tool, will have an immediate impact on enhancing workforce development training within Auburn University (AU), and within the state of Alabama at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Specifically, the development of this instrument has led to (i) the training of several students in core technical competencies at the intersection of engineering, combustion, chemistry and plasma sciences, which are all applicable to a wide range of technical sectors of industry and academia; and (ii) enhancing the educational experience in several courses taught by the PIs of the project to educate on concepts of energy sustainability and plasma physics. Finally, support for this work has uniquely positioned AU not only as an institution capable of educating a new generation of engineers and scientists with interdisciplinary technical skills, but also as a technical leader in the development and implementation of advanced combustion technologies in the state of Alabama, an NSF EPSCoR state.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Nicholas Tsolas
